You say here after I completed Special Forces MOS training in March 1970, we were all then assigned to a group.
At this time, fifth group was responsible for Vietnam and as warriors, everyone wanted to be assigned to fifth group, including myself.
However, there were two groups at Fort Bragg, sixth group and seventh group.
I was assigned to seventh group, like any good soldier you do as you are told and make the best of it.
I was proud to be a green beret.
That summer brought me to the Nhat Nha Lha.
I'm saying that right?
Nhat Nha Lha.
Nhat Nha Lha National Forest from which I was picked to be part of Bull Simon's mysterious mission.
So on September 2nd, 1970, as a member of the advanced party, we loaded on the C-123's southbound.
So, Bill Simon's, this guy is a legend.
World War II, he fought in New Guinea. He was a ranger. He conducted a raid.
That was a POW rescue they rescued in the Philippines. Over 500 POWs, many of whom had participated in the Baton Death March.
Then he'd gotten out for a couple years and then came back in.
He was in special forces. He was in SOG. I mean, this guy was a legendary guy.
How did that happen that you got picked for this mission? How'd you hear about the mission? How'd you get picked?
Well, I was up at Nhat Nha Lha and I was training. I was working with a bunch of master sergeants.
We were teaching mountain climbing and rope tying to officers and some of the guys in seventh group.
We needed some supplies. Colonel told me to go into town and pick up supplies.
Nhat Nha Lha is about no, probably 253 miles from Fort Bragg.
I went back down to Bragg and a couple of my buddies said, when I got down there, they said, hey, do you see where Bull Simon's is looking for volunteers?
Bull Simon's, I mean, that wasn't enough to excite you. You didn't want to be there.
I said, well, I'm going to go down and see what he's talking about because he said if you want to, he was going to be down at the, we call it a little White House there for Bragg.
I got down there. It was packed. I mean, never probably 500 plus special forces guys there.
Bull came out on the stage and he always had a little cigar in his mouth. He never smoked it. I don't know. He just chewed on it.
But I had never seen the guy. So that was kind of my first introduction to Colonel Simon.
He looks like a legend. His physical appearance, he looks like a legend.
He is a legend. I mean, he's, yeah, there's no doubt about that.
So when he came on stage, he said, I was looking for some volunteers who are moderately hesitant to smish him.
And I always wondered what he called hazardous compared to what we were getting ready to go and do.
But he said there's no TTY. So you know, not eliminated some guys. Everybody was temporary money, duty money.
And he said if you're interested, get back here and we'll start the interview process at that 1300 hours.
So I went back and put my name on the list and the next, I came back to, they had two Sergeant majors doing a lot of the interviewing.
Two Command Sergeant majors. And we were in and lying at the seventh group facility, Billets.
And he was about, no, probably about 530, I guess. And I was sitting there and nobody's calling me. Nobody's calling me.
Everybody else pretty much gone and out walks these two Sergeant majors. And they're walking out the door and I'm thinking, they didn't interview me.
And so I ran after him and hollered at him. I said, you know, hey, you guys didn't interview me.
And they said, what's your name? And I said, Buckler. And they said, well, and he had a clipboard on him.
Look at him. He says, I don't have your 201 file. That's the military and army. That's your file tells you everything about who you are and what you've done in your record.
And I said, they said, well, I'm on the interview and they said, well, you get your 201 file.
And I'll be back here first thing in a more and more interview. So, okay. So buddy man, at that time was one of my roommates, a bunch of us lived off base.
And we had seven of us in the sixth and seven of us in seventh group. So we were, only time we were together was painting in holidays.
And so we kind of, the neighborhood, I think was glad to see us move, but you know, he was a deputy sheriff to have done the road from us.
And he was always stopping by and saying, guys, can you just roll it down just a little bit. But anyway, I went in for the interview.
And they asked me if I could weld. And I said, I grew up on a farm and our neighbor Sam welded everything we ever broke.
I looked at that. I thought, I can do that. So I said, yeah, I'm a welder.
So you felt like you could weld because you watched your buddy weld.
I like it. I like your attitude. That's good attitude.
Yeah, I didn't, they didn't have a welder. So I wouldn't have to prove myself.
And then I want to know if I did scuba. And I, I had, at that point, done scuba. So I said, no, I don't know scuba.
And then he just asked me some general questions. You know, what, how much combat have you been? And I'm thinking, they got my two on one fall.
I have no combat experience. And so I said, no, I don't know. Then. So I said, okay. Well, thanks. I thought, well, at least they let me interview.
So, you know, thank you. And I walked out the door back up to Nata Hailey then and a couple of days later, a girl from our called me into his office up at the Nata Hailey there.
And he says, pack your bag. And I said, whoa, okay. He says, you made bullseymons list. And I said, really? And he said, yep. So I said, okay.
And I went, you know, I'm very excited, not even knowing what we're going to do just the fact that we made it.
Did you have any idea why they selected you to this day?
The only thing I could figure out is they needed some special forces aside from your crack welding skills.
And they're about that one, you know.
I think what they needed was some grunts and special forces. The knee five is the lowest rank.
So I was on the advanced party and we went down and set up the compound. And we, when they swept the building, we put the
contentine wire around and put the field phone out. And then I pulled guard duty on the bed. We had to guard that building 24 by seven.
And I thought it was a long user because when we pulled guard duty of bragging, you got to, you know, I'm 16 in one round. Maybe, you know,
and this one, we had an M16 in full round and orders if that goes south shoot. And that, I thought, there's something serious on this mission that they're not telling everybody.
But, you know, we did what we were told to do. And I pulled guard duty and when I went in pulling guard duty, I was either sleeping or training.
Because I had to train with the other guys during when I wasn't pulling guard duty.
